case_vignette: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his foster mother because of complaints from his teachers regarding poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He does not listen to their instructions, often talks during class, and rarely completes his school assignments. He does not sit in his seat in the classroom and often cuts in line at the cafeteria. His foster mother reports that he runs around a lot inside the house and refuses to help his sister with chores and errands. He frequently interrupts his foster mother's conversations with others and talks excessively. She has found him trying to climb on the roof on multiple occasions. He was placed in foster care because of neglect by his biological parents 3 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mental status examination shows a neutral affect.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble listening to my teachers, talking a lot in class, and not finishing my schoolwork.
Is this behavior recent or has it been going on for a long time?
It's been going on for the past 8 months.

Has this child been diagnosed with any medical conditions before?

[Final Diagnosis: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)]

trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Conduct Disorder.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq:
**Final Diagnosis:** Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

Based on the patient's symptoms of trouble focusing in class, talking excessively, and not finishing schoolwork, Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is the most likely diagnosis. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms can significantly impact a child's academic performance and social interactions. It's important to note that a definitive diagnosis should be made by a healthcare professional through a comprehensive evaluation.
